channel.title: Blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok
channel.description: People like blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok, where did they get their programming knowledge from? Say I wanted to build a server base, I wouldn't even know where to begin. How did they actually copy RuneScape back in 317/474 or even now, are there books that'll teach me the 3d rendering and multiplayer networking? Or am I going to have to wait and take courses at uni.

Scala is great with Java!

item.title: Blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“runeite51, post:23, topic:530392”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=649152.msg4365492#msg4365492 date=1379590080]

Well that’s how I was introduced to programming. I didn’t understand much but if-statement and ctrl+f was enough. Obviously I have to learn, but where? There aren’t any books or guides on how to make my own Hyperion or Apollo. Do I need to find books on model rendering? Or how multiplayer networks work? Shit I don’t even know what I need to know.

your own hyperion or apollo you’re thinking way too much ahead man, you gotta start with the basics

i can barely create a half-decent (not even half decent by some people’s standards) NIO framework and i’ve been programming from about late 2009/early 2010

if you get too ahead of yourself, you’re just going to waste your time trying to accomplish something that’s way too difficult for you
[/quote]

Right, and I know it will take time. I just wanted a vague picture of the steps I’d need to take to get there.

You need a good amount of design practice as well, as well as possibly being familiar with a scripting language

Yep yep. Ruby is a nice one to learn.

What about Python?[/quote]
So is Python.

I love JavaScript also.

Read full topic

if you get too ahead of yourself, you’re just going to waste your time trying to accomplish something that’s way too difficult for you[/quote]

Right, and I know it will take time. I just wanted a vague picture of the steps I’d need to take to get there.

[quote=“arham 4, post:22, topic:530392”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=649152.msg4365473#msg4365473 date=1379582863]

item.title: Blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok
item.dc:creator: @runeite51 runeite51
item.description:
@runeite51 wrote:

[quote=“Jaxus, post:15, topic:530392”][quote author=runeite51 link=topic=649152.msg4365100#msg4365100 date=1379494274]

Does anyone actually read this far up
[/quote]Because I’m sick of you and your belligerent posts. I’ll continue removing them until you sort out the attitude.

OT: Learning. Learning is essential. How did we learn how to do 2*2? By learning. How did we learn how to read this text? By learning.

The obvious conclusion to come to is that in order to progress in any field of study, you definitely have to learn.

@OP: I suggest that you do not start with any ‘big’ project if you are trying to learn something, because you will often end up confused and frustrated. This applies to private server emulation; if you don’t understand any part of the language associated with the content, you will not know how to solve the problem at hand. A lot of people will beg to differ, because many members of this community were introduced into the programming field via rs2 emulation, and it is very possible to learn Java from only working with a private server.

Please understand that this post is extremely opinionated by myself, and the learning process for everyone is different based upon your individual experiences with problem solving in general. I may have lost you by now, but if I still have you attention, let me just say that I prefer not to break down something big, making it simpler, but building from the ground up, and keeping it as simple as possible. Simplicity is key, and has turned out to be the best way to learn something (at least for me).

Well that’s how I was introduced to programming. I didn’t understand much but if-statement and ctrl+f was enough. Obviously I have to learn, but where? There aren’t any books or guides on how to make my own Hyperion or Apollo. Do I need to find books on model rendering? Or how multiplayer networks work? Shit I don’t even know what I need to know.

If you are working on a private server, it shouldn’t be necessary for you to learn model rendering, although learning about networking could be beneficial, I’m not quite sure you would even touch on it too much. The thing you have to realize is that learning Java and working on a game in Java are two completely different things. You will need to study the protocol of the emulation you are using, but you will need to have a grasp on Java in order to do so.[/quote]

Seems like if I knew enough Java, I’d just have to do is spend enough time with private servers to do the same types of things influential programmers here did. Hmm, I was under the impression sources like Hyperion were the emulation coded from the ground up.

Read full topic

item.title: Blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

[quote=“runeite51, post:14, topic:530392”][quote author=Jaxus link=topic=649152.msg4364977#msg4364977 date=1379465405]

Why the hell was my post removed???
[/quote]Because I’m sick of you and your belligerent posts. I’ll continue removing them until you sort out the attitude.

OT: Learning. Learning is essential. How did we learn how to do 2*2? By learning. How did we learn how to read this text? By learning.

The obvious conclusion to come to is that in order to progress in any field of study, you definitely have to learn.

@OP: I suggest that you do not start with any ‘big’ project if you are trying to learn something, because you will often end up confused and frustrated. This applies to private server emulation; if you don’t understand any part of the language associated with the content, you will not know how to solve the problem at hand. A lot of people will beg to differ, because many members of this community were introduced into the programming field via rs2 emulation, and it is very possible to learn Java from only working with a private server.

Please understand that this post is extremely opinionated by myself, and the learning process for everyone is different based upon your individual experiences with problem solving in general. I may have lost you by now, but if I still have you attention, let me just say that I prefer not to break down something big, making it simpler, but building from the ground up, and keeping it as simple as possible. Simplicity is key, and has turned out to be the best way to learn something (at least for me).

Well that’s how I was introduced to programming. I didn’t understand much but if-statement and ctrl+f was enough. Obviously I have to learn, but where? There aren’t any books or guides on how to make my own Hyperion or Apollo. Do I need to find books on model rendering? Or how multiplayer networks work? Shit I don’t even know what I need to know.[/quote]
If you are working on a private server, it shouldn’t be necessary for you to learn model rendering, although learning about networking could be beneficial, I’m not quite sure you would even touch on it too much. The thing you have to realize is that learning Java and working on a game in Java are two completely different things. You will need to study the protocol of the emulation you are using, but you will need to have a grasp on Java in order to do so.

Read full topic

@OP: I suggest that you do not start with any ‘big’ project if you are trying to learn something, because you will often end up confused and frustrated. Please understand that this post is extremely opinionated by myself, and the learning process for everyone is different based upon your individual experiences with problem solving in general. I may have lost you by now, but if I still have you attention, let me just say that I prefer not to break down something big, making it simpler, but building from the ground up, and keeping it as simple as possible. Simplicity is key, and has turned out to be the best way to learn something (at least for me).[/quote]

Well that’s how I was introduced to programming. I didn’t understand much but if-statement and ctrl+f was enough. Obviously I have to learn, but where? There aren’t any books or guides on how to make my own Hyperion or Apollo. Do I need to find books on model rendering? Or how multiplayer networks work? Shit I don’t even know what I need to know.

OT: Learning. Learning is essential. How did we learn how to do 2*2? By learning. How did we learn how to read this text? By learning.[/quote]
The obvious conclusion to come to is that in order to progress in any field of study, you definitely have to learn.

@OP: I suggest that you do not start with any ‘big’ project if you are trying to learn something, because you will often end up confused and frustrated. This applies to private server emulation; if you don’t understand any part of the language associated with the content, you will not know how to solve the problem at hand. A lot of people will beg to differ, because many members of this community were introduced into the programming field via rs2 emulation, and it is very possible to learn Java from only working with a private server.

Please understand that this post is extremely opinionated by myself, and the learning process for everyone is different based upon your individual experiences with problem solving in general. Simplicity is key, and has turned out to be the best way to learn something (at least for me).

item.title: Blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

OT: Learning. Learning is essential. How did we learn how to do 2*2? By learning. How did we learn how to read this text? By learning.

At the time, we thought it was so difficult to do so, but in the end, it was easy. Same thing now.

We don’t remember that feeling when we were trying to read for the first time because we didn’t have much of a brain. Now that we have a brain, we see things as ‘hard’, but in reality, its just as hard as it way to learn how to read and write.

Read full topic

item.title: Blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:6, topic:530392”]Years of experience. Really, if you’re dedicated, you can match their knowledge within a year or two. That would be a bit insane, however, so I’d put it at around 4-5 years if you’re being casual yet still inspired.

Once you get enough knowledge, you should try making your own projects unrelated to private servers. You’ll learn a lot more very quickly. The graph of the learning experience definitely wouldn’t be linear, either.[/quote]

It’s not insane if you study daily and get at least one subject of the language completed within a day.

Read full topic

item.title: Blakeman8192, b00mer, graham, taharok
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Years of experience. Really, if you’re dedicated, you can match their knowledge within a year or two. That would be a bit insane, however, so I’d put it at around 4-5 years if you’re being casual yet still inspired.

Once you get enough knowledge, you should try making your own projects unrelated to private servers. You’ll learn a lot more very quickly. The graph of the learning experience definitely wouldn’t be linear, either.

Read full topic
